Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: Small: DCM: DA: Advancing real-time data processing and reduction in radio astronomical detectors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This award is to support development and test the accelerated, efficient reconstruction and beam-forming algorithms for radio astronomical detectors. When possible, computations will be ported out to the Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) clusters that provide massively parallel floating-point capabilities. This approach is ideally suited to the data generated by digital radio astronomy arrays, and especially well suited when the respective hardware is deployment at remote observation sites - because of the proposed algorithms show excellent performance-to-power efficiency when compared to general-purpose supercomputers. Additionally, the real-time (Field Programmable Gate Arrays) FPGA-based algorithms will be developed for radio transient data reduction. They will help developing accelerated radio simulation methods to support and validate the proposed methodology. These algorithms and methodology will be tested at the Askaryan Radio Array (ARA), an array of in-ice antennae deployed in the U.S. Antarctic South Pole Station to detect highest-energy neutrinos coming from the deep Universe sources. The award's broader impacts are in the use of high-performance parallel computing and efficient real-time data reduction in the fields of radio astronomy, cosmology, and particle astrophysics. Expansion of the use of GPUs will provide the necessary computing power for next-generation experiments in a sustainable, efficient way. The post-doctoral researcher and graduate student will be part of the overall development and testing. In addition, undergraduate students will also be involved in the research. An on-line public research component will be developed to engage "citizen scientists" in the analysis of radio astronomy data on home computers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in digital signal processing (DSP) have fueled a renaissance in the fields of radio astronomy, cosmology, and particle astrophysics. Low-cost, high-speed signal digitizers and supporting DSP hardware allow the construction of huge radio telescopes and radio particle detector arrays, each consisting of a large number of individual antenna elements.

However, these instruments generate a huge amount of digital data which can easily overwhelm storage, processing, and data transmission capabilities, especially if these arrays are located at remote sites.  High-speed network infrastructure and supercomputing-power processing capability are not feasible for many remote experiments.

We are part of international collaborations that are building two digital radio astronomical experiments: the Hydrogen Structure Array (HSA) in remote China, a radio telescope designed to measure the emission of neutral hydrogen and to map the large-scale structure of the Universe; and the Askaryan Radio Array (ARA), an array of antennas deployed in the South Pole ice sheet to detect the highest-energy neutrinos in the Universe. These experiments share the need to coherently combine digital time-domain signals, using the method of interferometric beamforming. In this proposal, we have combined our efforts and expertise to solve this common BIGDATA challenge.

Over the course of this project, we have developed accelerated, efficient reconstruction and beamforming algorithms for radio astronomical detectors using Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) clusters, which provide massively parallel floating-point capabilities ideally suited to data from our digital radio arrays, and are especially well-suited to deployment at remote sites because of their excellent performance-to-power efficiency, compared to general-purpose supercomputers.

Specifically, we have achieved the following goals with this research:

  • we have developed a GPU-accelerated neutrino event reconstruction algorithm to reconstruct the direction to an ultra-high-energy neutrino interaction using the time delays of the radio signals to ARA antenna clusters;
  • we have implemented fast software tools to calculate the paths of radio waves through the South Pole ice, necessary for neutrino event reconstruction, and released this as open source software;
  • we have developed multiple filter algorithms to separate neutrino radio signals from the large background of thermal noise;
  • we have designed a new algorithm for extracting faint signals from neutral hydrogen in radio telescope data.
  • we have improved our triggering hardware to more effectively reject noise in favor of neutrino signals

Our research has broadened the use of high-performance parallel computing and efficient real-time data reduction in the fields of radio astronomy, cosmology, and particle astrophysics. Expansion of the use of GPUs provides the necessary computing power for next-generation experiments in a sustainable, efficient way. By promoting the scientific use of computing hardware designed originally for the consumer market, we have widened the availability of these resources to the scientific community, as well as expanding the specialized knowledge of how to use this hardware successfully for research. To disseminate our work, we have leveraged our existing programs to engage the public and involved undergraduates directly in our research.
